abstractText: In some parameter and solution regimes, a minimally coupled nonrelativistic quantum particle in 1d is isomorphic to a much heavier, vibrating, very thin Euler-Bernoulli rod in 3d, with ratio of bending modulus to linear density (ħ/2m). For m = me, this quantity is comparable to that of a microtubule. Axial forces and torques applied to the rod play the role of scalar and vector potentials, respectively, and rod inextensibility plays the role of normalization. We show how an uncertainty principle ∆x∆px ∼ ħ governs transverse deformations propagating down the inextensible, force and torque-free rod, and how orbital angular momentum quantized in units of ħ or ħ/2 (depending on calculation method) emerges when the force and torque-free inextensible rod is formed into a ring. For torqued rings with large wavenumbers, a “twist quantum” appears that is somewhat analogous to the magnetic flux quantum. These and other results are obtained from a purely classical treatment of the rod, i.e., without quantizing any classical fields.

sections.text:
Dynamics of certain Euler-Bernoulli rods and rings from a minimal coupling quantum isomorphism
T. A. Engstrom∗
Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Northern Colorado, Greeley, CO 80639, USA (Dated: June 8, 2023)
In some parameter and solution regimes, a minimally coupled nonrelativistic quantum particle in 1d is isomorphic to a much heavier, vibrating, very thin Euler-Bernoulli rod in 3d, with ratio of bending modulus to linear density (ℏ/2m)2. For m = me, this quantity is comparable to that of a microtubule. Axial forces and torques applied to the rod play the role of scalar and vector potentials, respectively, and rod inextensibility plays the role of normalization. We show how an uncertainty principle ∆x∆px >∼ ℏ governs transverse deformations propagating down the inextensible, force and torque-free rod, and how orbital angular momentum quantized in units of ℏ or ℏ/2 (depending on calculation method) emerges when the force and torque-free inextensible rod is formed into a ring. For torqued rings with large wavenumbers, a “twist quantum” appears that is somewhat analogous to the magnetic flux quantum. These and other results are obtained from a purely classical treatment of the rod, i.e., without quantizing any classical fields.
I. INTRODUCTION
Mathematical analogies between quantum mechanical systems and vibrating elastic systems have been made since the earliest days of quantum mechanics, when in 1926, Schrödinger observed that the “square” of what we now think of as the time-dependent Schrödinger equation resembles the equation of motion of a vibrating plate [1, 2]. Looking at this in reverse, the EulerBernoulli operator for a freely vibrating plate can be factored into two Schrödinger-like operators: ∂2t + ∆
2 = (i∂t + ∆)(−i∂t + ∆), a property useful in certain solution schemes [3, 4], while it has similarly been shown that the Föppl-von Kármán operator describing large deflections of the plate can be factored into two nonlinear Schrödinger-like operators [5]. However, such analogies are fundamentally limited by the fact that the real, scalar transverse plate deflection or some derivative thereof stands in for a complex wavefunction. A closer continuum elastic analogy can be made to one-dimensional quantum mechanics, and this involves a rod or elastica that deflects in two transverse dimensions. Here the components of the deflection vector (or even more powerfully, as we will see, the components of the transverse projection of the tangent vector) can play the roles of Re[Ψ] and Im[Ψ]. While aspects of the 1d quantum - 3d rod analogy have appeared in the literature before, the focus has been on time-independent phenomena [6–11], specific forms of interaction relevant to semiflexible polymer systems [6–8], and nonlinear effects such as bend-twist coupling [9, 10], rather than on pushing the linear timedependent analogy to the point of becoming an isomorphism, as we do here.
The value of such an isomorphism is, of course, in the potential to learn something about elastic systems from quantum systems, and vice versa, just as analogies
∗ tyler.engstrom@unco.edu
between the band structure of electronic systems and vibrations of isostatic frames [12], metamaterials [13], jammed packings [14], and continuous plates with patterened resonators [15] have recently been used to predict the existence of topologically protected edge modes in the latter four. As a more historic example, de Gennes showed that quantum fluctuations of a 1d Fermi gas can be mapped to thermal fluctuations of 2d polymeric systems (albeit flexible, not semiflexible polymers), where a “no-crossing” condition for polymer chains plays the role of Fermi statistics [16]. While both the quantum and classical elastic systems considered here are comparatively simple, we nevertheless gain some surprising new insights. We find, for example, that de Broglie relations and uncertainty principles govern momentum-carrying transverse deformation pulses in periodic, inextensible, force and torque-free rods, and that vibrating inextensible rings may carry quantized orbital angular momentum reminiscent of spin. Additionally, a vibrating rod that experiences a spatially periodic body force, such as might be generated by internal interactions, can constitute a classical analog of a 1d Bloch electron (distinct from a phononic crystal in that the vibrations are flexural). The key to all this turns out to be the higher order and therefore virtually unused “squared” Schrödinger equation.
The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section II develops the quantum side of the analogy and Section III develops the elastic side, as generally as possible. Section IV concerns a specific elastic application, namely the ring or periodic rod mentioned above, for which the analogy lends considerable insight. We end in Section V with suggestions to use the analogy to explore new physics.

sections.heading: II. MINIMAL COUPLING FORMALISM
sections.text:

where R(π/2) is a π/2 rotation matrix, H̃ denotes the matrix of operators on the right hand side of Eq. (1),
and Ψ⃗(r, t) = (Ψ1(r, t),Ψ2(r, t)) is a vector function in the now real, but 2×higher dimensional Hilbert space: R2(Rd) versus C(Rd). (To avoid ambiguity, we use arrow notation and boldface for vectors in R2 and Rd, respectively.) Transforming Eq. (2) by operating on both sides with R(π/2)ℏ∂t yields
−ℏ2∂ttΨ⃗ = H̃2Ψ⃗ +R (π 2 ) ℏ[∂t, H̃]Ψ⃗. (3)
When [∂t, H̃] = 0, in other words when H̃ changes at most adiabatically slowly, Eq. (3) is the real-valued counterpart of what is sometimes called the “squared” Schrödinger equation.
The Hamiltonian of interest in this work is the minimal coupling Hamiltonian

When d = 1, A = Ax is constant with respect to x (e.g., Landau gauge), and A,V have adiabatically slow or no time-dependence, Eq. (3) with (5) can be written as the following set of coupled equations:
−ρΨ̈1 = BΨ′′′′1 +MΨ′′′2 + (PΨ′1)′ +KΨ1 + CΨ′2 + (C ′/2)Ψ2, (6a) −ρΨ̈2 = BΨ′′′′2 −MΨ′′′1 + (PΨ′2)′ +KΨ2 − CΨ′1 − (C ′/2)Ψ1. (6b)
Dots and primes denote partial derivatives with respect to t and x, respectively, while B/ρ = (ℏ/2m)2, M/ρ = ℏqA/m2, P/ρ = −V/m − 3M2/8ρB, K = (P + M2/4B)2/4B+P ′′/2, and C = P (M/2B)+B(M/2B)3.

sections.heading: III. DYNAMICALLY AND HELICALLY BUCKLED ROD
sections.text:
Equations (6) come from an isomorphic rewriting of a problem in d = 1 quantum mechanics, but in this Section, we attempt to reinterpret them as classical elastic equations of motion for an object living in R3 = R2⊗Rd. Such a reinterpretation requires neglecting certain terms that have no clear physical meaning in the elastic context, yet these terms involve parameters that do have physical meaning in the elastic context. The conditions on the parameters (and solution regimes) under which these extra terms are negligible establish the limits of validity of the analogy.
With this philosophy in mind, we momentarily ignore the last two terms on the right hand sides of Eqs. (6), and notice that what remains are the 3d equations of motion of an Euler-Bernoulli beam with circular cross section, hereafter, a rod. Table I suggests its scale. The rod undergoes transverse deflection from the x-axis pro-
portional to Ψ⃗, has mass per unit length ρ and bending modulus B, and sustains both an axial moment (torque) M and an axial body force P (x). (P > 0 where the rod is in compression and P < 0 where it is in tension.) Notice that P accounts for twist-induced tension, sug-
gesting the internal structure of the rod is a bundle of inextensible fibers [18]. This picture is consistent with a single-valued bending modulus for the composite rod structure provided there is no cross-linking [17]. The rod also experiences a “substrate” force, e.g., from being embedded in an elastic gel, with force constant per unit length K(x). The case of Eqs. (6) with M = K = C = 0 and P > 0 is known as the dynamical buckling equation [19–21], yet the extra features described above are well-studied extensions of linear buckling [22–24], if not typically together and in a dynamical context. Counterintuitively, even when a rod is everywhere in tension it
3 can buckle given suitable boundary conditions [25]. The case of Eqs. (6) with P = K = C = 0 describes flexural vibration of a rod with pre-twist [26].
As x→ 0, the second and fifth terms on the right hand sides of Eqs. (6) can be combined into ±(MΨ′2,1)′′ where M(x) =M+C(x)x2/2. So for part of the rod, the physical effect of C is to generate a variable axial moment [24]. However, this coefficient doesn’t appear to have a simple physical interpretation that is valid for the entire rod, and so to make Eqs. (6) precisely analogous to an elastic system, we must neglect (and justify neglecting) the C and C ′ terms. To do this we introduce the rod length L and note three different cases.
Case 1: Spatial derivatives of P are negligible, and ML/B and PL2/B are both ≪ 1 so that we may retain terms only to linear order in these quantities in the nondimensionalized equations of motion (lengths measured in units of L, time in units of L2 √ ρ/B). On the quantum side, this case corresponds to the semiclassical approximation with weak potentials. On the elastic side, it corresponds to small terminal twist angle ϕ = (1+ν)ML/B where ν is Poisson’s ratio, and P well below the Euler buckling threshold π2B/L2. Equations (6) reduce to
−ρΨ̈1 = BΨ′′′′1 +MΨ′′′2 + PΨ′′1 , (7a) −ρΨ̈2 = BΨ′′′′2 −MΨ′′′1 + PΨ′′2 . (7b)
To linear order in ML/B, the twist-induced tension contribution to P is not accounted for, and all elastic parameters become independent of one another. Incidentally, static helically buckled rod configurations described by Eqs. (7) map onto the dynamics of a symmetric top that remains nearly upright and has its bottom point fixed, an instance of the Kirchhoff kinetic analogy [22].
Case 2: For solutions composed entirely of shortwavelength (λ ≪ L) Fourier modes, and for P slowly varying on the scale of λ, the low-derivative-order terms on the right hand sides of Eqs. (6) can be negligible, even when their coefficients are not necessarily small. Specifically, for the C terms to be negligible compared to the M terms we require (2πL/λ)2 ≫ p/2 + ϕ2/8 and for the K terms to be negligible compared to the P terms we require (2πL/λ)2 ≫ p/4 + ϕ2/8 + ϕ4/64p, where we have defined p = PL2/B and set ν = 0 for simplicity. This allows for modest values of twist ϕ, for example four complete twists when P is near the Euler threshold and λ ≪ L/4, yet still corresponding to small torsional strain since the latter is equal to ϕ divided by the (extremely large) aspect ratio of the rod. Equations (7) also apply to this case.
Case 3: M = 0 (or removed via a gauge transformation) and P (x) is an arbitrary function. Equations (6) uncouple and there is a special relationship between the elastic parameters: K = P 2/4B+P ′′/2 ≈ P ′′/2 when P is small. In general the substrate term vanishes when P is the solution of an Emden-Fowler equation.
Here through Section IV we mostly focus on Cases 1 and 2, and at the end of Section V we return to Case 3.

FIG. 1. Arbitrary small 3d deformation produced by subjecting a straight inextensible rod (oriented along x̂) to a relative compression γ (shown greatly exaggerated). The vector function Ψ⃗ = Ψ1ŷ+Ψ2ẑ appearing in the expression for the rod’s unit tangent vector t̂ satisfies a “squared” Schrödinger equation (Eqs.(7)) as well as a normalization-like constraint.
The essentially constant coefficients in Eqs. (7) mean that
Ψ⃗ can now be interpreted as any scaled derivative of the rod’s transverse deflection u⃗(x, t) = u1(x, t)ŷ + u2(x, t)ẑ. A particularly compelling choice is Ψ⃗ = u⃗′/ √ 2γL, as this gives rise to a geometrical constraint 1 = ∫ dxΨ⃗ · Ψ⃗ if the rod is inextensible, i.e., if the contour length of its centerline does not change. Here L is redefined as the projected (onto the x-axis) length of the rod, and γ is its relative compression (not to be confused with axial strain, and not necessarily implying that P > 0). Figure 1 shows
this geometry, and how Ψ⃗ becomes a scaled transverse projection of the rod’s tangent vector. The inextensibility constraint written above is the leading order term in an expansion and so is valid only when u⃗′ · u⃗′ ≪ 1 everywhere, meaning γ ≪ 1. Inextensibility is a good assumption for semiflexible polymers — it being an ingredient of the wormlike chain model [17] — and is consistent with the internal structure of the rod inferred earlier, even though that structure is not accounted for at linear order in ML/B. So setting aside the broader analogy that
can be made without specifying Ψ⃗ in favor of the deeper one that can be made by assigning Ψ⃗ = u⃗′/ √ 2γL to an inextensible rod, we proceed with the latter assignment except where otherwise noted. Thus, there exist “normalized” solutions of Eqs. (7) of the form
Ψ⃗(x, t) = ∑

where (H̃/ℏ)ψ⃗n = ωnψ⃗n, δnm = ∫ dx ψ⃗n ·ψ⃗m, 1 = ∑ n c 2 n,
4 and in rod language,

(9) Note the identity R(α) = exp[αR(π/2)], Euler’s for-
mula for 2d rotations. The ψ⃗n are, in general, nonplanar due to M , they rotate at angular frequencies ωn, and they correspond to stationary states. That is, if ψn = ψn,1 + iψn,2 is an eigenstate of Ĥ with eigenvalue
En, then ψ⃗n = (ψn,1, ψn,2) is an eigenstate of H̃ with the same eigenvalue. While the above described solution is not the only form of solution to Eqs. (7) — more gen-
erally, the ψ⃗n satisfy the “squared” eigenvalue equation (H̃/ℏ)2ψ⃗n = ω2nψ⃗n —we focus on this form since it is also a solution of the lower order Eq. (2) with (9) and therefore gives maximum contact with quantum mechanical methods and results.
The linear Eqs. (7) are agnostic as to whether ρ is mass per unit length in the x-direction or mass per unit contour length (the local conversion factor being 1+γLΨ2), and therefore, we are free to choose the latter definition, which is the more realistic for an inextensible rod. A consequence is that purely transverse vibration of the inextensible rod is associated with a longitudinally propagating momentum. One way to see this is by combining the continuity equation ∂t[ρ(1 + γLΨ
2)] + ∂xg = 0 with Eqs. (2) and (9) to obtain the momentum density
g(x, t) = −2γL √ ρB [ Ψ⃗ ·R (π 2 ) Ψ⃗′ + M 4B Ψ2 ] . (10)
Comparing to the quantum mechanical momentum density, i.e., m times the probability current −(ℏ/m){Re[Ψ∗iΨ′] + (qA/ℏ)|Ψ|2}, leads to the identification
ℏ = 2γL √ ρB, (11)
in terms of rod parameters. Putting this in the relationship B/ρ = (ℏ/2m)2 further identifies m = γρL. This result makes intuitive sense: the rod has mass ρL (to leading order), and so the pulse mass set in motion by a relative compression γ is γρL (to leading order). In other words, the isomorphism connects a massive quantum particle with a much more massive (by a factor of γ−1) elastic rod. For a field theoretic perspective on the rod’s momentum density, we introduce the Lagrangian density
L = 1 2
[ ρ( ˙⃗u)2−B(u⃗′′)2−Mu⃗′ ·R (π 2 ) u⃗′′+P (u⃗′)2 ] , (12)
from which Eqs. (7) can be obtained. The last two terms represent energy stored by twisting and work done by P , and within Case 1, i.e., to linear order in ML/B, these terms are isomorphic to −Aµjµ of classical electrodynamics. This follows from our previous results qAµ = −γL(P, √ ρ 4BM, 0, 0) and j µ/q ↔
(Ψ2, g/ργL, 0, 0). Calculating the relevant component of the energy-momentum tensor
Tαµ = [ ∂L ∂ui,α − ∂β ( ∂L ∂ui,αβ )] ui,µ + ∂L ∂ui,αβ
ui,βµ − δαµL, (13)
derived in Appendix A, gives momentum density g = −T 01 = −ρ ˙⃗u · u⃗′, which matches Eq. (10) when M = P = 0. (To see this, use u⃗ as the dependent variable in Eq. (2), which is a valid procedure within Cases 1 and 2 as discussed above.) For yet a third perspective, consider the following geometric argument due to Rowland and Pask [27]. Setting up a waveform in an initially straight inextensible rod requires that one end of the rod move by a distance γL = 12 ∫ L 0 dx(u⃗′)2 toward the other, as shown in Figure 1. If the waveform has only one spectral component, then the solution has the property u⃗′ = − ˙⃗u/ẋ, where ẋ is the phase velocity (we will see a specific example in Section IV). Substituting this for one factor of u⃗′ in the integrand yields ∫ dt ˙(γL) = − 12 ∫ dt ˙⃗u·u⃗′, hence g = − 12ρ ˙⃗u·u⃗′, half of that predicted by the other two methods when M = P = 0. Rowland and Pask point out that this geometric argument gives the correct result for inextensible strings, and in that linear dispersion context the waveform need not be restricted to one spectral component.

sections.heading: OR PERIODIC ROD
sections.text:
To illustrate why the factor of 2 discrepancy in g poses an interesting question, we consider the nth helical eigenstate and corresponding eigenfrequency of Eq. (9):
ψ⃗n(x) = 1√ L R(knx)ŷ, (14a)
ωn = √ B ρ ( 2π L )2[( n− ϕϕ0 )2 − 3 ( ϕ ϕ0 )2 − p8π2 ] ,(14b)
where kn = 2πn/L, M/4B = 2π(ϕ/ϕ0)/L, and ϕ0 = 8π(1 + ν). This describes a mode of vibration of a rod with periodic boundary conditions; alternatively, it describes a continuous ring of radius L/2π if we neglect effects of the undeformed ring’s curvature (compare the model in Ref. [19]). Such neglect is justified when the ring is very slender (R/L → 0), and in any case, accounting for the curvature would introduce corrections to P andK that couple only to the in-plane component of Ψ⃗ [20, 23] — interesting, but incompatible with the isomorphism here. The ring deflection corresponding to Eqs. (14) is, up to a rigid translation of the guiding center,
u⃗n(x, t) = − √ 2γ
kn R(knx− ωnt)ẑ, (15)
and one can readily verify that u⃗′n = −(kn/ωn) ˙⃗un as required by the geometric argument. Letting the plane of the ring be perpendicular to the z-axis, (L/2π) ∫ L 0 dxg yields orbital angular momentum
5 Lz =
   ℏ ( n− ϕϕ0 ) , g from continuity equation, ℏ ( n− 2 ϕϕ0 − 1 n [ 2 ( ϕ ϕ0 )2 + p8π2 ]) , g from energy-momentum tensor,
ℏ ( n 2 − ϕ ϕ0 − 1n [( ϕ ϕ0 )2 + p16π2 ]) , g from geometric argument.
(16)
The first two methods predict Lz is quantized in units of ℏ when M = P = 0, while the third method intriguingly predicts Lz is quantized in units of ℏ/2 whenM = P = 0. Of course, when we say “units of ℏ” we are assuming the factor of length change γL in ℏ is independent of n, which is not intuitive for elastic rings. And yet the isomorphism is describing a particular elastic ring for which γL is indeed independent of n. Next we consider nonzero M and P within a sub-case of Case 2 corresponding to 4π2L/λ ≫ p/2 + ϕ2/8. Within this sub-case the terms ∼ 1/n in Eq. (16) are negligible, and the Lz spectrum becomes periodic in ϕ with period ϕ0 or ϕ0/2, depending on method. Thus ϕ0 (or ϕ0/2) plays a role comparable to that of the flux quantum for a conducting loop in a magnetic field [28, 29], just not in a thermal equilibrium sense since here the total energy (found by changing the signs of the last three terms in Eq. (12) and integrating over x) is not also periodic in ϕ. Letting Eqs. (14) describe the periodic straight rod and setting M = P = 0 yields a set of de Broglie relations: px = ∫ dxg = ℏkn (using one of the first two methods for g) and E = ℏωn (equal parts kinetic and potential energy and also applicable to the ring). There is also orbital angular momentum Lx = ∫ dxρu2nωn = ℏ, which makes the rod reminiscent of an OAM beam [30]. Now suppose the rod is sufficiently long that we can take the kn to be continuous. The general t = 0 state of the rod is given by
Ψ⃗(x, 0) = 1√ 2π
∫ dk R(kx)Ω⃗(k), (17)
where Ω⃗(k) is the continuum generalization of cnŷ in Eqs. (8) and (14a). The relationship between Ψ⃗(x, 0)
and Ω⃗(k) is isomorphic to that of a Fourier transform
pair, as shown in Appendix B. Thus if Ω⃗(k) is a peaked vector function with characteristic peak width ∆k, then
Ψ⃗(x, 0) describes a transverse deformation with characteristic length ∆x (as in the lower image of Figure 1), and by a property of Fourier transforms, ∆x∆k >∼ 1. This inequality is generic and unremarkable, but when combined with the first de Broglie relation for the rod, it becomes the rather more remarkable Heisenberg uncertainty principle
∆x∆px >∼ ℏ. (18)
An energy-time uncertainty principle follows from the other de Broglie relation: a transverse deformation pulse of spatial extent ∆x moving at the group velocity ∂ω/∂k ∼ ∆ω/∆k takes time ∆t ∼ ∆x∆k/∆ω >∼ 1/∆ω
to pass a particular point, hence
∆t∆E >∼ ℏ. (19)

sections.heading: V. DISCUSSION
sections.text:
Conventional wisdom has it that Eq. (18) is fundamentally quantum mechanical, foreign to classical mechanics. While this may be true for classical mechanics of particles, it is evidently not so for classical mechanics of elastic continua. One might argue that ℏ would not appear in any purely classical theory, but we again point to Table I which demonstrates that a rod with ratio of bending modulus to linear density equal to (ℏ/2me)2 is comparable to a microtubule or in fact something a bit heavier — a classical object indeed. And recall that the right hand side of Eq. (18) can be written purely in terms of classical rod parameters, per Eq. (11). It is somewhat unsatisfying that three different methods give three different results for g, and thus the inextensible ring’s Lz, but a few comments are in order. First, the geometric argument makes use of a γ = 0 reference state that is distinct from that of other two methods, and also appears to have no counterpart in the quantum problem. (A complex wavefunction that is “stretched out” beyond the extent of its real-space domain is an unphysical concept.) Second, the previously mentioned equipartition of energy when M = P = 0 suggests that half of the g obtained from the first two methods may actually be a pseudo-momentum density associated with potential energy transport. This has also been suggested for inextensible strings [27]. Third, recall that quantum mechanics itself suffers from method dependence: half-integer angular momenta defy an apparently rigorous separation of variables method but yield to an algebraic method. Indeed, the possibility of the inextensible ring’s Lz being quantized in units of ℏ/2 hints at the notion of the ring as a particle-like entity. We have seen that this “particle” would have mass greater by a factor of γ−1 than the mass m of some corresponding particle. If m = me, which again suggests taking B and ρ values from a microtubule, then we may crudely estimate γL = ℏ/2 √ ρB ∼ 10−17 m, and crudely estimate the ring’s mass to radius ratio as 2πme/γL ∼ 10−12 kg/m. The slenderness requirement (L ≫ microtubule radius) leads to an estimate γ ≪ 10−9; for γ this small, the EulerBernoulli description and the form of the inextensibility constraint we have used are essentially exact. Attempting to further constrain γ and L would be an interesting direction for future work.
6 Another future direction concerns the analog of wavefunction collapse. Conventionally in dynamical buckling (whereM = K = 0 and P is a positive constant), one assumes that a perturbation with wave number k grows at rate σ(k). This leads to a prediction that the fastestgrowing, hence, most probable mode is the one with k = √ P/2B, a result that is in good agreement with experiments on rings confined to buckle in plane [19]. (As the authors point out, this agreement can be taken as evidence that the ring curvature is negligible for slender rings, as we have assumed in Section IV.) The natural question to ask in the present context, however, is not which mode is selected out of an unbuckled state, but which mode is selected out of a superposition state? Because Eq. (18) is linked to the statistical interpretation in quantum mechanics, its presence here also hints at a statistical interpretation, i.e., that the c2n may be probabilities of the outcomes of measurements, such as of the straight rod’s Lx = ∫ dxρu2ω.
Finally, let us return to Case 3, where Ψ⃗ ∼ rod deflection and P (x) is an arbitrary function. A convenient property of the isomorphism is that if PL2/B is a weak sinusoidal function, so is (KL4/B) ≈ (PL2/2B)′′. This suggests engineering out-of-phase sinusoidal variations in the axial body force and in the substrate stiffness. One way to achieve the former could be by manipulating intrachain interactions in a stiff polyelectrolyte — already implicated in buckling [8] — by creating an alternating pattern of charged and neutral monomer blocks [31]. If such a polymer were made to vibrate in a non-dissipative environment of similar polymers, all parallel to and in registry with the first, the effective K from that environment should oscillate out of phase with P and be tunable in strength through the environment density. Eigenstates of Eq. (9) would then be expected to have the Bloch form
ψ⃗n,k(x) ∼ R(kx)w⃗n,k(x), (20)
where n is a band index and the function w⃗ has the periodicity of the monomer pattern. Assuming such a system could be realized experimentally, one might then imagine adiabatically varying the boundary conditions — certain of which are equivalent to twist via a gauge transformation — to search for more exotic physics such as the Zak phase [32], but in a classical setting.

sections.heading: Appendix A: energy-momentum tensor
sections.text:
The energy-momentum tensor, a.k.a. the stress-energy tensor, is usually derived assuming the Lagrangian density depends on field variable derivatives only up to first order. Here we derive it (in the notation of Ref. [33]) for a Lagrangian density such as Eq. (12) that depends on field variable u(x) derivatives up to second order:
L = L(u,∇u,∇∇u, x). The Euler-Lagrange equations are
∂L ∂ui − ∂α ∂L ∂ui,α + ∂αβ ∂L ∂ui,αβ = 0. (A1)
Under an ϵ-family of transformations of the field variables, and writing δ ≡ d/dϵ at ϵ = 0,
δL = ∂L ∂ui δui + ∂L ∂ui,α δui,α + ∂L ∂ui,αβ δui,αβ . (A2)
Combining the previous two equations yields
δL = ∂α [{
∂L ∂ui,α
− ∂β (
∂L ∂ui,αβ
)} δui +
∂L ∂ui,αβ δui,β
] .
(A3) Now if ϵ parameterizes a displacement of the origin by an arbitrary four-vector hµ, i.e., ui(x
µ) → ui(xµ+ϵhµ), then δui = h µ∂µui and δL = hµ∂µL = ∂α(hµδαµL). Hence
0 = ∂αT α µ , (A4)
where
Tαµ = [ ∂L ∂ui,α − ∂β ( ∂L ∂ui,αβ )] ui,µ + ∂L ∂ui,αβ
ui,βµ − δαµL. (A5)

sections.heading: Appendix B: Fourier transform analog
sections.text:
Due to the existence of an Euler’s formula for 2d rotations: exp[αR(π/2)] = I cosα + R(π/2) sinα = R(α), we can write down analogs of the Fourier transform for vector functions in R2. These are
ξ⃗(x) = 1√ 2π
∫ dk R(kx)ξ⃗(k), (B1a)
ξ⃗(k) = 1√ 2π
∫ dxR(−kx)ξ⃗(x), (B1b)
with Dirac delta functions given by
Iδ(x) = 1
2π
∫ dk R(kx), (B2a)
Iδ(k) = 1
2π
∫ dxR(kx). (B2b)

title: Dynamics of certain Euler-Bernoulli rods and rings from a minimal coupling quantum isomorphism
